facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos.1682 to 1684 of 1970 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1969 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in R.C. No. 4 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos.1682 to 1684 of 1970. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1969 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in R.C. No. 4 of 1966.

facts.text: The appeals arise from a reference under section 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 relating to assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57 of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: These are appeals by Special Leave. They arise from a common judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in a reference under section 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, to be hereinafter referred to as the Act. The reference in question relates to the assessment of the assessee for the assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-

facts.text: The question of law referred by the Tribunal is whether the assessments made on the firms for assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57 are valid in law.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law referred by the Tribunal is Whether on the facts and the circumstances of the case, the assessment made on the firms, for each of the assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57, are valid in law ?

facts.text: Up to and including assessment year 1953-54, the business was carried on by Vadde Pallaiah and he was assessed as an individual.

anchor.surface_text: Now we shall set out the material facts as could be gathered from the case stated by the Tribunal. Up to and including the assessment year 1953-54 business with which we are concerned in this case, was carried on by Vadde Pallaiah. He was assessed as an individual.

facts.text: On March 20-3-1953, Vadde Pallaiah entered into a partnership consisting of himself and three others known as M/s. Vadde Pullaiah Co.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20-3-1953 he entered into a partnership consisting of himself and three others. That partnership was known as M/s. Vadde Pullaiah Co.

facts.text: In the partnership, Pullaiah had 8 as. share, two partners had 3 as. share each, and one had 2 as. share.

anchor.surface_text: In that partnership Pullaiah had 8 as. share and out of the remaining three partners two had 3 as. share each and one had 2 as. share.

facts.text: For assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57, the firm filed returns of income as a firm and applied for registration under section 26A.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57, this firm filed returns of income as a firm. It also applied for registration under section 26A.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the registration application holding there was no genuine firm and assessed Pullaiah as individual.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected that application holding that there was no genuine firm. He came to the conclusion that the business was exclusive that of Pullaiah. He accordingly assessed Pullaiah as an individual in respect of the income earned in that business.

facts.text: Firm and Pullaiah appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: As against that order both the firm as well as Pullaiah went up in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held the firm was genuine, allowed appeals, directed registration of firm and set aside Pullaiah's assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner after examining the material before him came to the conclusion that the firm in question was a genuine firm. Consequently, he allowed the appeal of the firm as well as that of Pullaiah. In the firms appeals, he directed the Income-tax Officer to register, that firm and in Pullaiahs appeal he set aside the assessment made on him.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer proceeded to assess the firm for assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: After this order was made, the Income-tax Officer proceeded to assess the firm in respect of the income earned by that firm during the assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956- 57

facts.text: Firm resisted assessment claiming barred by limitation under section 34(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: When the Income-tax Officer initiated proceedings against the firm for the purpose of assessment, the firm resisted the same taking the plea that the proceedings in question is barred by limitation under section 34(3) of the Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the limitation contention.

anchor.surface_text: He rejected that contention.

facts.text: Firm appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner who upheld the limitation contention and set aside ITO's order.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that order the firm went up in appeal to the Appellate, Assistant Commissioner. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the contention of the, assessee and set aside the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer appealed to Income-Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: As against that order the Income tax Officer went up in appeal to the Income-Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal held assessments for 1955-56 and 1956-57 not barred by limitation due to Second Proviso to section 34(3), but 1954-55 barred.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal partly accepted the appeal of the Income-tax Officer It came to the conclusion that the assessment in respect of assessment years 1955-56 and 1956-57 are not barred in view of the Second Proviso to section 34(3) of the Act. But it opined that the assessment in respect of the assessment year 1954-55 was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax and assessee moved Tribunal under section 66(1) for reference to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the Tribunal both the Commissioner of Income-tax as well as the assessee moved the Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Act to refer certain questions of law to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Tribunal referred the question to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal submitted the question set out earlier to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in favour of assessee holding assessments barred by time and not saved by Second Proviso to section 34(3).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has answered that question in favour of the assessee. It came to the conclusion that the impugned assessments were barred by time and they are not saved by the Second Proviso to sub-section (3) of section 34 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order, answered question in affirmative in favour of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above we set aside the order of the High Court. We vacate the answer given by the High Court and answer the question referred to in the affirmative and in favour of the Revenue.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner found the business was carried on by the firm and not by Pullaiah.

anchor.surface_text: But in the body of his order he specifically held that the business. in question was carried on by the firm and not by Pullaiah.

facts.text: Pullaiah was the dominant partner with 8 as. share and original owner of the business.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case Pullaiah was the dominant partner of the firm as found by the Tribunal. He had 8 as. share in the firm. He, was the original owner of the firm.
